title: Lesson 1: Greetings
text: Greetings are an essential part of Kyrgyz culture. The most common way to say hello is “Салам!” (Salam!). A more polite form is “Саламатсызбы?” which means “How are you?”.
grammar:
Present Simple of “to be” in Kyrgyz is often omitted in the present tense.

Мен мугалим. – I am a teacher.
Сен студент. – You are a student.
Ал дарыгер. – He/She is a doctor.
Биз досторбуз. – We are friends.
Силер окуучуларсыңар. – You are students.

title: Lesson 2: Numbers
text: Numbers are used in everyday conversation for counting, time, age, and more. Here are the basic numbers from 1 to 10 in Kyrgyz:
grammar:
Numbers in context don’t require plural endings for counted nouns.

Бир китеп – one book
Эки дос – two friends
Үч алма – three apples
Төрт бала – four children
Он машина – ten cars

title: Lesson 3: Family
text: Family is very important in Kyrgyz culture. The word “үй-бүлө” means “family”. Let’s learn some common family terms.
grammar:
Possessive forms are made by adding suffixes:

Менин атам – my father
Сенин энең – your mother
Анын агасы – his brother
Биздин үй-бүлөбүз – our family
Силердин досторуңар – your friends

title: Lesson 4: Pronouns
text: Pronouns are essential for constructing sentences. Below are the basic Kyrgyz personal pronouns.
grammar:
Pronouns in use:

Мен студентмин. – I am a student.
Сен жакшысың. – You are good.
Ал келди. – He came.
Биз барабыз. – We are going.
Алар окушат. – They study.

title: Lesson 5: Plural Nouns
text: Plural nouns in Kyrgyz are formed with the suffixes –лар, –лер, –дор, –дөр, depending on vowel harmony.
grammar:
Plural endings agree with vowel harmony:

Кыз – кыздар (girls)
Эне – энелер (mothers)
Адам – адамдар (people)
Көл – көлдөр (lakes)
Жол – жолдор (roads)
